title: Will the Philippines participate in the 2017 Balikatan military exercise?
preds:
1st PH-US Balikatan exercises under Duterte open
Up to 2,600 American soldiers are in the Philippines to join the Balikatan 2017 exercises with 2,800 of their Filipino counterparts, an annual activity that President Rodrigo Duterte wanted scrapped last year as he threatened to cut ties with the United States.
http://www.rappler.com/nation/169168-balikatan-duterte-opening-philippines
Affirming forecast for the passage of time.
Well it's a terrible reason to go from 96 to 100 but everyone else is doing it.

News banner with specific dates:
Update Philippines, April 24, 'Balikatan 2017 to take place May 8 to 19': http://www.update.ph/2017/04/balikatan-2017-to-take-place-may-8-to-19/16977 Affirming forecast.

"U.S., Philippines scale back next month's military drills, no more 'war games'.
(...)
"A Philippine army spokesman said the downsizing of the exercises was in response to Duterte's dislike of war games with Washington. "We made some adjustments, based on the pronouncements of the president that such exercises should be focused on humanitarian operations," Major Frank Sayson told reporters. "Just to make it clear, this is not a war game." Sayson said the two sides agreed to scrap two major military drills – Amphibious Landing Exercise or "Phiblex" and Cooperation Afloat and Readiness Training (CARAT) - geared toward external and maritime defense. He said the two armies would work on marksmanship and defusing of homemade bombs, as part of counter-terrorism exercises." http://www.reuters.com/article/us-philippines-usa-defence-idUSKBN17Q120

http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2017/04/16/1690867/philippines-us-hold-military-drills MANILA, Philippines — The Philippine military said Sunday it would hold annual exercises with US troops next month, reaffirming its commitment to the alliance despite cooling relations under President Rodrigo Duterte.

The 10-day exercises will be the first held under Duterte, who has suggested canceling the drills and called for the withdrawal of American troops, putting into question Manila's 70-year-old alliance with Washington as he looks instead to court China.

PhilStar, April 16, 'Philippines, US to hold military drills': http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2017/04/16/1690867/philippines-us-hold-military-drills
Comments: Yup. Affirming forecast for the passage of time.
Read a report that there won't be war games. Does this affect the question?

Asian Journal, April 5, 'Philippine-US military exercises to begin this month': http://asianjournal.com/news/philippine-us-military-exercises-to-begin-this-month/
Clip from article:
"According to reports from Rappler, U.S. troops are expected to arrive in April for outreach activities. The war games will begin in May." Affirming forecast.
It appears to be going to happen, and it is probably too late to cancel if either President gets annoyed with the other.

Rappler, March 31, 'U.S. Navy destroyer makes port call in Subic': http://www.rappler.com/nation/165790-us-warship-fitzgerald-subic
Clips from article:
"The US warship arrived at the former US naval base in Subic as the Philippine and US militaries prepared for the first Balikatan war games under President Rodrigo Duterte, whose foreign policy places emphasis on forging stronger ties with countries like China and Russia.
The Balikatan is the biggest of dozens of joint activities between the two allies bound by a Mutual Defense Treaty. Duterte previously threatened to scrap the annual joint military exercises, but was prevailed upon to do otherwise. He imposed limitations on the war games instead." Affirming forecast.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
No news items of cancellation, and with less time for it to happen now seems unlikely.
Affirming forecast for the passage of time.
Duterte has been saying he'll do this for so long now that it would be difficult for him to back off.  He is deeply unpleasant but not especially mercurial.
Update.PH, March 9, 'US-Philippines Balikatan 2017 set next month': http://www.update.ph/2017/03/us-philippines-balikatan-2017-set-next-month/15504 Comment: On for April. Affirming forecast.

The “Balikatan” military exercise between the Philippines and the United States will push through in this city next month, Ormoc City Mayor Richard Gomez said. Gomez said he is amenable to hosting the military exercise as it will help improve the peace and order situation in the city.
http://www.update.ph/2017/03/us-philippines-balikatan-2017-set-next-month/15504
No date mentioned yet, but the exercise will be all the more prestigious with Japan participating.
Affirming forecast for the passage of time.
Depends on how Duterte feels on the day

ASEAN Neutrality: A Strategic Windfall For China Tata (2017) Feb. 24, states that: China will likely receive a strategic windfall over the next decade as each of the member countries of the Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN) increasingly embrace neutrality along the lines of Finland, Sweden or Switzerland— an unintended consequence of Washington’s withdrawal from the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) trade initiative. From the perspective of the ASEAN countries (the Philippines, Thailand, Malaysia, Brunei, Indonesia, Singapore, Myanmar, Laos, Cambodia and Vietnam), this U.S. economic disengagement from Asia is a leading indicator of a shift in American grand strategy away from an expansive, multi-faceted approach involving economic, political and military dimensions to one that is more narrowly focused on a military security strategy aimed at establishing a virtually impregnable defensive line (in a conventional military sense) in the Western Pacific running from Japan through Guam to Australia. Beijing’s challenge will be how to take advantage of this window of opportunity to consolidate peacefully its embryonic 21st-century version of the Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere. Far from being a threat, the current incarnation of “America First” may well be a boon to Beijing. Strategic Importance of ASEAN Neutrality A key element of the Middle Kingdom’s grand strategy is to foster the neutrality of southeast Asian states in the event of serious conflict between Beijing and Washington. Ultimately, ASEAN neutrality means that no member country would host military facilities for the regular use of outside powers. From Beijing’s national security viewpoint, southeast Asia is critical for two reasons. First, many of the countries—most importantly the Philippines, Vietnam, Malaysia, Brunei and Indonesia—have overlapping and competing maritime claims in the South China Sea that could significantly impede China’s efforts to establish a maritime cordon sanitaire beyond the customary 12-nautical-mile line along its eastern seaboard. Second, the countries sharing common land borders with China (Myanmar, Laos and Vietnam) serve as a buffer protecting China’s vulnerable southeastern underbelly. Clearly, Beijing would prefer that its southeast Asian neighbors are not hostile and avoid policies that could adversely impact China’s vital national security interests. To further this objective, Beijing has embraced an approach using the persuasive allure of soft power—economic, financial and cultural incentives and inducements, with occasional demonstrations of coercive power, military actions and rhetorical saber rattling, to dissuade ASEAN member countries from banding together (and cooperating with the U.S.) to counterbalance China, and to encourage them to remain neutral in any larger struggle between Beijing and Washington over East Asian dominance. China’s economic power provides the gravitational pull to keep the ASEAN countries within its sphere of influence. China is the economic engine of Asia, having displaced both the United States and Japan as the most important trading partner of the ASEAN countries. China is the single-largest provider of bilateral economic development aid to them. In addition, China is sponsoring multilateral institutions (from which the U.S. is conspicuously absent) such as the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), New Development Bank (NDB or BRICS Bank) and the BRICS Contingent Reserve Arrangement (BRICS CRA) to further reinforce and identify its central role in funding Asian economic development. The collapse of the American-sponsored TPP trade initiative due to the withdrawal of U.S. support provides a clear path for Beijing to assume the mantle of leadership and promote the Comprehensive Regional Economic Partnership (CREP), the regional trade alternative originally proposed by ASEAN and enthusiastically backed by China. Of course, there is an important cultural dimension that potentially enhances Beijing’s economic soft power, as there are significant minority-ethnic Chinese communities with deep local roots and prominent commercial roles in each of the southeast Asian countries (with ethnic Chinese constituting the majority population of Singapore) (para. 1-3). Tata, S. (2017) ASEAN Neutrality: A Strategic Windfall For China. Forbes. Opinion. Foreign Affairs. Retrieved from 
https://www.forbes.com/sites/realspin/2017/02/24/asean-neutrality-a-strategic-windfall-for-china/#2ed2879b7b11

ASEAN unsettled by China weapon systems, tension in South China Sea Mogato (2017) Tue Feb 21, states that: Southeast Asian countries see China's installation of weapons systems in the South China Sea as "very unsettling" and have urged dialogue to stop an escalation of "recent developments", the Philippines said on Tuesday. 
The region's foreign ministers were unanimous in their concern over China's militarization of its artificial islands, but were confident a framework for a code of maritime conduct could be agreed with Beijing by June, Philippine Foreign Secretary Perfecto Yasay said. 
Yasay did not say what developments provoked the concern, but said the 10-member Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN) hoped China and the United States would ensure peace and stability. 
He said demilitarization would be a key component of any ASEAN-China code of conduct, but it was too soon to say whether Beijing's dismantling of its weapons installations would be a prerequisite. 
"The ASEAN members have been unanimous in their expression of concern about what they see as a militarization of the region," Yasay told reporters after a ministers' retreat on the Philippine island of Boracay. 
Referring to China's manmade islands in the Spratly archipelago, Yasay said ASEAN countries had "noticed, very unsettling, that China has installed weapons systems in these facilities that they have established, and they have expressed strong concern about this." 
With the Philippines chairing the bloc this year, Yasay's comments signal a rare, firm position by a grouping that often struggles to achieve consensus, due to its contrasting opinions on how to respond to China's assertiveness (para. 1-7). Mogato, M. (2017) ASEAN unsettled by China weapon systems, tension in South China Sea. Reuters. World News. South China Sea. Retrieved from 
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-asean-philippines-idUSKBN1600I3
Affirming forecast for the passage of time.

I think this is a toss-up because of Trump trying to balance needs/goals:  to appear strong against China's provocations in the area, but not jeopardize a possible trade deal, and (at the same time) keep the Philippine relationship from deteriorating further.  I worry more that Trump will do something that will make any Philippine - US exercises meaningless....
Duterte said last year that the 2016 Balikatan exercise would be the last.

Given the warm personal relations between Trump and Duterte, I believe the US-Philippines alliance is once again being strengthened so the exercises will certainly go ahead. That said, both men are prickly and changeable so I subtract one point for each of those character flaws they share.

China, U.S. Warplanes Had ‘Unsafe’ South China Sea Encounter Tweed (2017) February 10, states that: Two military aircraft from China and the U.S. had an “unsafe” encounter over a disputed part of the South China Sea, the U.S. Pacific Fleet said on Friday, the first publicly confirmed incident since May last year.
A People’s Liberation Army Air Force KJ-200 surveillance plane had “an interaction characterized by U.S. Pacific Command as ‘unsafe’” with a Navy P-3C Orion surveillance aircraft, Pacific Command Spokesman Major Robert Shuford said in an e-mail. CNN earlier reported the planes flew within 1,000 feet of each other in the general vicinity of the Scarborough Shoal.
“We will address the issue in appropriate diplomatic and military channels,” Shuford said. “The U.S. Navy P-3C was on a routine mission operating in accordance with international law.”
An unidentified defense ministry official told the state-run Global Times the Chinese pilots took legitimate and professional measures to deal with the encounter. The official added the U.S. should seek to minimize air or sea incidents with China, according to the report.
Tensions between the U.S. and China are elevated as President Donald Trump threatens higher tariffs on Chinese products and questions the U.S. approach to Taiwan, which Beijing considers part of its territory. In his confirmation hearings, Secretary of State Rex Tillerson said the U.S. should deny China access to artificial reefs it built in the South China Sea (para. 1-5). Tweed, D. (2017). China, U.S. Warplanes Had ‘Unsafe’ South China Sea Encounter. Reuters. World News Retrieved from
https://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2017-02-10/china-u-s-warplanes-had-unsafe-encounter-in-south-china-sea

Updating forecast dramatically. http://asianjournal.com/news/ambassador-kim-ph-us-to-maintain-2017-joint-exercises/
The Philippine ambassador says its on. Still, I wonder if President Duterte won't kill the event since he has warmed up to China.

Downgraded prediction based on Duterte's public embrace of China, Trump's unstable leadership vs. Xi, and US withdrawal from TPP. Did not take into account US Ambassador Kim's recent declaration to continue exercise, though.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Ambassador Kim: PH-US to maintain 2017 joint exercises
http://asianjournal.com/news/ambassador-kim-ph-us-to-maintain-2017-joint-exercises/

South China Sea Duterte Is Getting Ready For The Next Flip Flop Mourdoukoutas (2017) January 30, states that: Philippines President Rodrigo Duterte is getting ready for yet another flip-flop in articulating his county’s South China Sea policy. This time around he is about to re-align with the US.
Last month, Manila filed a protest before the Chinese Embassy over Beijing's reported military buildup on the islands and reefs in the contested Spratly Islands in the South China Sea.
The protest comes one month after President Duterte promised to respect defense treaties with “friend” and “ally,” the United States, and two months after Manila warmed up to Beijing and announced a “divorce” from Washington.
Investors get unsettled with high profile flip-flops. They magnify political risks, which add to other investment risks. That's especially the case for countries like Philippines suffering from persistent political instability since the fall of Ferdinand Marcos in 1986, as Ruchir Sharma observes in The Breakout Nations.
That's why Philippines’ equity markets headed south after Duterte flip-flopped.
What made Duterte change his mind this time around? 
It’s hard to say. One plausible answer is China’s ongoing aggression, telling America to stay away from its “own” South China Sea. And sending a warning message to Taiwan in the form of a naval force demonstration – recently, a group of Chinese warships that included the country’s only aircraft carrier made its way to the South China Sea after passing south of Taiwan in a “routine” exercise.
Another plausible answer is a recent survey, which showed 84 percent of Filipinos want Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte to assert his country's rights over its territories in the South China Sea.
A third plausible answer is a new administration in Washington, which has promised to contain China’s South China Sea ambitions.
Keeping a record on Philippines’ President’s position on South China Sea disputes is a rather tricky task. Duterte’s flip-flops can be traced back to last July after an international arbitration ruling, which found that China has no historic title over the waters.
That was a big victory for both the Philippines, which had filed the arbitration case, and its close ally the US, which wants those waterways to be an open sea (para. 1-11). Mourdoukoutas, P. (2017). South China Sea: Duterte Is Getting Ready For The Next Flip-Flop. Forbes. Markets. Foreign Affairs. Retrieved from
https://www.forbes.com/sites/panosmourdoukoutas/2017/01/30/south-china-sea-duterte-is-getting-ready-for-the-next-flip-flop/#7c907e9b3153 Philippines says U S military to upgrade bases defense deal intact Mogato (2017) Thu Jan 26, states that: The United States will upgrade and build facilities on Philippine military bases this year, Manila's defense minister said on Thursday, bolstering an alliance strained by President Rodrigo Duterte's opposition to a U.S. troop presence.
The Pentagon gave the green light to start the work as part of an Enhanced Defense Cooperation Agreement (EDCA), a 2014 pact that Duterte has threatened to scrap during barrages of hostility towards the former colonial power.
"EDCA is still on," Defense Secretary Delfin Lorenzana told a news conference.
EDCA allows the expansion of rotational deployment of U.S. ships, aircraft and troops at five bases in the Philippines as well as the storage of equipment for humanitarian and maritime security operations.
Lorenzana said Washington had committed to build warehouses, barracks and runways in the five agreed locations and Duterte was aware of projects and had promised to honor all existing agreements with the United States.
This week, Republican U.S. Senator John McCain, who headed the U.S. Senate's Armed Services Committee, proposed $7.5 billion of new military funding for U.S. forces and their allies in the Asia-Pacific.
The geopolitical landscape in Asia has been shaken up by Duterte's grudge against Washington, his overtures towards erstwhile adversary China, and the election of U.S. President Donald Trump, whose administration has indicated it may take a tough line on China's activities in the South China Sea (para. 1-7). Mogato, M. (2017). Philippines says U.S. military to upgrade bases, defense deal intact. Reuters. World News. Retrieved from
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-philippines-usa-defence-idUSKBN15A18Z?il=0

It looks like PHIBLEX is canceled, but Balikatan is still on [1] [2]. [1] http://www.militarytimes.com/articles/no-phiblex-in-2017
[2] http://asianjournal.com/news/ambassador-kim-ph-us-to-maintain-2017-joint-exercises/
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

The Manila Bulletin, January 26, 'Lorenzana: US to build, fix facilities in PH camps under EDCA': http://news.mb.com.ph/2017/01/26/lorenzana-us-to-build-fix-facilities-in-ph-camps-under-edca/
Clips from article:
"Lorenzana said President Rodrigo Duterte is aware of the situation.
“He’s okay with it, he’s okay with EDCA. He said we will honor all agreements that were entered into by the previous government,” Lorenzana said.
EDCA—a supplemental agreement to the existing visiting forces agreement (VFA) between the Philippines and the U.S.—was signed by former defense secretary Voltaire Gazmin and former United States ambassador to the Philippines Philip Goldberg in Manila on April 28, 2014." Incremental adjustment up.
Perceives he is safe not to engage in this activity at present

Even during the row over U.S. bases in the Philippines, the Filipino defense minister and other military parties seemed to downplay the seriousness of Duterte's statements, indicating that they view the U.S. as an important ally to balance China and wish the relationship to continue. I believe that the election of Donald Trump will allay the row between the Philippines and the U.S. Trump has thus far narrowed American foreign relations to issues of trade and security. As a result, Duterte and his ego will feel safer against criticism from a powerful corner, and will be more willing to tone down his rhetoric and work with the United States. His recent appeal to Muslim separatist rebels against Islamic State also indicates a deficit in his ability to counter terrorist forces that the U.S. could bolster--a mission that aligns heavily with current U.S. foreign policy goals. Additionally, the Philippines is a linchpin in the U.S.'s strategy to counter Chinese expansion in the region, and Donald Trump made challenging China a top tenet of his campaign. I doubt that friction over U.S trade barriers will arise before the exercises take place in the spring.  Finally, the recent announcement by Duterte to the effect that the U.S.-Filipino alliance is intact (as well as confirmation of Japanese involvement in the exercises) almost guarantees that they will take place.  http://www.reuters.com/article/us-philippines-usa-defence-idUSKBN15A18Z http://www.reuters.com/article/us-philippines-security-idUSKBN15B0XO

50% - > 45%
Rationale: Trump cancelled TPP. 
Australia would like to go on with TPP with Asean partners only and also looking to China, but Japan doesn't without the USA
Australia participated in Balikatan last year with Phil and USA while Japan was an observer. 
Japan announced to participate this year in Balikatan, but I could not find anything on the website of the Australian Dept of Defence.    
Very complex situation making it in my eyes less likely that Phil will participate in Balikatan.

Duterte actions on drug addicts and drug dealers, and his strong man vision is probably less of issue for Trump than it was for Obama. As Trump wants to also be a strong man and has listed drugs as part of the US problem they may be able to share policy tips. Trump's inaugural speech seemed to imply that he was not inclined to criticize leaders of other countries. That should appease  Duterte.  It has been reported that Japan intends taking part in the exercise this year, so it seems they think it will take place.  (I am not convinced of the reliability of the source, they are suggesting at Malania Trump has copied other First Ladies, this must surely be fake news)    
http://beta.philstar.com/headlines/2017/01/14/1662145/japan-join-phl-us-balikatan

In October 2016 Duterte said that they will not join next year's exercise. Situation/ relationship between both countries might change with the new president in place. On the other side increased tensions between the US and China might also result in the Philippines moving closer to China as Duterte has recently announced "friendship" with China
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Rationale 
Japan announced to join in this year's joint Balikatan. In a normal world this should mean something close to 100%. 
Unpredictable Trump x unpredictable Duterte = lake full of black swans.

Japanese forces will join this year’s joint Balikatan military exercises between the Philippines and the United States, a Tokyo official said yesterday.
http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2017/01/14/1662522/japan-join-phl-us-balikatan Third party participation makes cancellation less likely.

From 14 to 50%
Rationale
Japan announced to join in this year's joint Balikatan. In a normal world this should mean something close to 100%.
Unpredictable Trump  x  unpredictable Duterte = lake full of black swans.

See @scholarandcat January 14 post and comments. Up-vote 1. See also earlier December 11, Military Times article affirming AFP participation, 'Philippines curtails military exercises with U.S.': http://www.militarytimes.com/articles/no-phiblex-in-2017
Clips from Times article:
"The U.S. military relationship with the Philippines is shifting back to its original focus on being prepared for humanitarian assistance and disaster relief missions, Baker said. 
“That’s what we always used to do, and that’s what we do with Balikatan, and that’s why they didn’t cancel Balikatan,” he said, referring to another joint military exercise between the two countries." I also see continuing benefits for the AFP by maintaining some military relationship with USA:
1) Money and equipment.
2) Compatibility with weapons.
3) Advanced training, including access to US jungle warfare centers;
'Welcome to the Jungle - 25th ID trains jungle experts': https://www.army.mil/article/155880/Welcome_to_the_Jungle___25th_ID_trains_jungle_experts
'Jungle Warfare Training Center - 3d Marine Division': http://www.3rdmardiv.marines.mil/Units/Jungle-Warfare-Training-Center/
4) Language (English spoken).

I see two routes to a Yes answer: 1) Duterte leaves office and is replaced by a more traditional leader (very unlikely due to Duterte's popularity, but I'll say 1%)
2) Improved relations between Duterte and Trump lead to resumption of the exercises. I think the odds are low because it would interfere with Duterte's bridge-building with China. I'll say 15%.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Japan has accepted an invitation to participate.  http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2017/01/14/1662522/japan-join-phl-us-balikatan The only reason I am not higher is that a date for the exercise has not been announced yet.

I am just a simple algorithm. On each question, Iook at those players whom I follow, and copy the forecast of one of the several who have made the most recent forecasts. I only use my own judgment when deciding which one to follow if several have made recent forecasts. So far, this works pretty well. An Oct 2016 article in which President Duterte was said to have given the order that the Philippines would cease exercises with the US.  http://www.sunstar.com.ph/manila/local-news/2016/10/12/duterte-no-more-us-ph-balikatan-exercises-2017-503155

According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Duterte and Trump have publicly proclaimed their admiration of each other. Duterte realizes that to survive, he needs to play the US against China.

Duterte said that the 2016 exercise would be the last one. President elect Trump said the USA should not solve all the problems of the world.  Philippines won the courtcase against China about the Chinese sea, but China ignores any decisions by 'The Hague'. Eventual need form the USA  doesn't mind when it is about characters. If Duterne put up a finger to the UN why not to the USA? So why should the USA have this joined exercise. USA has to concentrate on Middle East, and North Korea. For the latter working together with Japan is more obvious. Both leaders are very poor listeners to their advisers (to put it mildly). On the other hand it has to be mentioned that Trump choose quite a number of (former) military staff in his Cabinet. Unlikely would be between 10-33% and very unlikely between 5-10%. Average of both classes would make 14%. Both can change opinion over night and are completely non-reliable on their own statements. So with these two leaders you never know and have to stay very far away from anything certain close like 0% or 100%. Following Sami Virtanen and far away from concensus.
The Philippines cannot ignore the growing Chinese threat in the South China Sea.
This time, this year, with this President. All bets off after this.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Duterte has said it more than once that he doesn't want the exercise.
Philippines likes having the US take care of their security. They only want money from China, not their military support.
Duerte is crazy and the Chinese are pulling his strings, this domino, along with the South China island/missile stations along the nine dash line -- will mean an invasion of Taiwan by the CCP.

Will the US cancel the annual appointment? Unlikely; military presence in the area still countsWill the Philippines cancel the appointment? Also unlikely, strongman Duterte will use any means to show off and shine in the light of the force of any partner that bolsters his position. So that brings it to a hefty 90%.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
There is not a gun game out there that Dutarte does not like! Including the Yankee ones! As for the last exercise, I doubt it , this country depends of US $ and policies to survive.
Trump is the new president. Duterte like Trump. He make so much noise but withdraw when his adviser remind him or when he come to his sense.

The ASEAN Crisis, Part 1: Why the South China Sea Is a Critical Test Tong (2016) December 21, states that: Arms Race and Regional Insecurity
The most prominent threat is the militarization in the South China Sea. in February 2016, China deployed 32 advanced surface-to-air missiles on Woody Island in the Paracels, distressing the United States and China’s neighbors in ASEAN. In addition, in response to the ruling of the Permanent Court of Arbitration at The Hague that Chinese claims over 90 percent of the South China Sea area are illegitimate, China remained defiant. Chinese officials even implicitly threatened to establish an Air Defense Identification Zone to control aircraft movements over her claimed territory, which shows Chinese willingness to act unilaterally despite non-recognition from other states (para. 5).
As the major counterbalance in the region, the United States responded by persistently operating “freedom of navigation exercises” as well as joint military patrols with the Philippines and potentially Japan, Australia, and Indonesia. Furthermore, the U.S. also enlarged her financial support for enhacing the military capabilities of ASEAN and East Asian countries and strengthened bilateral defense collaboration with these countries.
China’s rival claimants in ASEAN also reacted by increasing their defense budget. Compared to other ASEAN countries, Vietnam had the most significant enlargement, a 113 percent increase in defense expenditure in the 2004-2013 period. Vietnam spent $3.4 billion for military advancement in 2013 alone. Furthermore, Vietnam also actively engaged in strategic arms trade talks with India, Russia, and the U.S. since 2014.
Manila also moved to upgrade its military. The Philippines announced $885 million would be spent on purchase of “three guided-missile fast attack craft, two guided-missile stealth frigates, and two anti-submarine helicopters.” As a traditional ally of the United States, the Philippines also actively participated in bilateral military exercises with the U.S. and Japan in 2015 under former President Benigno Aquino. And despite the earlier disruption between new President Rodrigo Duterte and U.S. President Barack Obama, the Philippines reasserted her commitment to military cooperation with the U.S. in 2016 (para. 5-8). Tong (2016). The ASEAN Crisis, Part 1: Why the South China Sea Is a Critical Test. Foreign Policy. Retrieved from
http://thediplomat.com/2016/12/the-asean-crisis-part-1-why-the-south-china-sea-is-a-critical-test/

Duterte must beef up his strong man reputation in the eyes of those fed up with what is seen as interference in the daily life of everyday folks by outsiders whether it's drug cartels or political cartels. Duterte would not be able to justify the costs that could be better spent on the local economy. The only thing that would change this is more aggressive posturing by China and China may do that to prod Trump into offending Duterte to break up their bromance and weaken the US image abroad.

Military ties will persist despite cooling in the overall relationship - with the possible exception of any exercises or joint activity specifically aimed at China. Duterte will be at pains not to offend.
Trump invited Duterte to the WH already. Duterte disrespected Obama but with a fresh start and no official cancellation already I have to fall on the "it will happen" side.

As recently as in Dec, various military statements have confirmed Balikatan exercise will continue, but the nature of the exercise will change to one focused on disaster recovery, rather than a military exercise. Risk is Duerte's ongoing threats to scrap all engagements with U.S and the equation between him and Trump

What you going to do when the Punisher has you in his sights!  MANILA, Philippines — Hours after threatening to scrap the country’s Visiting Forces Agreement (VFA) with the US, President Rodrigo Duterte imposed one condition to Washington if it wants the deal retained.

“You want to come back here? You pay us. You want bases here? Pay us. Transaction tayo, pera-pera na lang tayo, mabuti pa (Let’s enter into a transaction. Let’s make it all about money. We would be better off like that),” Duterte said in a speech delivered in General Santos Saturday night.

“There are no wars right now, why would I allow you here? You want to create World War III? If you do that, if all the nuclear explosives are really (used), this planet won’t be around tomorrow. It’s the end for all of us, so why would be pick up a fight with anybody?”

The 1987 Constitution prohibits the establishment of foreign military bases in the country “except under a treaty duly concurred in by the Senate and, when the Congress so requires, ratified by a majority of the votes cast by the people in a national referendum.”The charter also states that the other contracting state should also recognize the agreement as a treaty.

“According to the Supreme Court, the VFA is a, Visiting Forces Agreement is an executive agreement, hindi, hindi (not a) treaty. So, start packing your things. Start packing your things and get out of my country,” Duterte said.

The VFA, which was signed in 1998, is a bilateral agreement that allows Filipino and American soldiers to conduct joint trainings in Philippine soil. It was ratified by the Senate in 1999 despite protests by militant groups who believe it would undermine Philippine sovereignty.

Easier to not do something than to do it.
Duterte will likely follow through with his threats.  He now has too much personal credibility invested in them and will not want to lose face.
The Philippines and the US need each other. The US to keep influence in the Eastern side of the South China Sea, the Philippines to get military and financial support.

“They (US) do not look at us kindly. We have this huge problem… Actually, we do not need it. We can survive without American money. But you know, America, you might also be put to notice. Prepare to leave the Philippines. Prepare for the eventual repeal or the abrogation of the Visiting Forces Agreement,” he added.

Signed in 1998, the VFA allows American and Filipino troops to conduct joint trainings in Philippine soil.

U.S. Philippines start planning Balikatan 2017 Update PH (2016) June 20, states that: American and Filipino military personnel attended the initial planning session for Balikatan 2017 at Camp H.M. Smith, Hawaii on June 16, 2016.
Balikatan is the premier military exercise between Philippines and United States. It is being held in the country every year.
This allows the two countries to work side-by-side together, whether it be combat or humanitarian-related.
“I am pleased to note that ‘Balikatan’ was a culmination of a year-long series of other events supporting the Armed Forces of the Philippines’ capability development, carried out in the direction of the Mutual Defense Board and Security Engagement Board,” US Marine Corps Forces, Pacific commander Lt. Schogol (2016) December 11, states that: For the first time in 34 years, the U.S. and Philippines will not hold the annual amphibious joint exercise PHIBLEX in 2017, the latest sign of strain in the two countries’ relationship since Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte was elected in May. 
More than 1,400 Okinawa-based Marines and sailors from the 3rd Marine Expeditionary Brigade, and 500 Philippine troops participated in the 33rd annual PHIBLEX this October. The annual exercise involved live-fire events, as well as training for amphibious landings. 
But in 2017, the two countries will hold a different training exercise, one that is more limited in scope and focused on amphibious operations in response to natural and man-made disasters, officials said. 
“PHIBLEX included a wider range of capabilities, ranging from command and control, mobility, maneuver, logistics, and territorial defense to humanitarian assistance and disaster relief missions,” said Chuck Little, a spokesman for Marine Corps Forces, Pacific. 
The exercises slated for 2017 will include training for cybersecurity, maritime security and counter terrorism, said Capt. Rachel Nolan, a liaison officer for the U.S. in Manila.  
“We reached a mutually agreed upon plan for 2017, which ensures that U.S.-Philippine military training activities and engagement remain robust and substantial,” Nolan said (para 1-6).
The U.S. military relationship with the Philippines is shifting back to its original focus on being prepared for humanitarian assistance and disaster relief missions, Baker said (para. 11).
“That’s what we always used to do, and that’s what we do with Balikatan, and that’s why they didn’t cancel Balikatan,” he said, referring to another joint military exercise between the two countries.
In September, Defense Secretary Ash Carter called the relationship between the U.S. and the Philippines ““ironclad;” however, Philippine Defense Minister Delfin Lorenzana told reporters on Dec. 8 that his country would likely not allow U.S. ships and planes to use his country for patrols in the South China Sea. 
The rough patch between the U.S. and the Philippines may turn out to be short-lived. Duterte seems to enjoy a much warmer relationship with President-Elect Donald Trump, who has reportedly invited Duterte to the White House (para. 11-14). Schogol, J. (2016). Recent news items state that despite President Duterte's comments that planning for the 2017 Balikatan exercise is underway. Long history of Balikatan exercises between the 2 countries (this years was the 32nd), therefore despite uncertainty it seems more likely than not they will continue in 2017.

There's naturally a lot of factors at play here and the main problem is both heads of state say one thing and then turn around and do the other. Duterte and Trump share common ground and have a state visit in the works http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/12/philippines-roger-duterte-donald-trump-invitation-161202192230991.html, which may or may not happen, and may or may not have any bearing on a potential military exercise. There has been planning going on already for the 2017 exercise https://www.dvidshub.net/feature/Balikatan and the understanding from the US viewpoint would seem to be that the exercise will go ahead since there has been no statement from their side to the contrary. Duterte may want to pivot towards China and Russia and as a gesture of reliability could cancel the military exercise. There is also the nuance that the exercise may well go ahead with a significant reduction in US involvement and number of troops attending, with them playing a more advisory role. This option is probably the most likely one.

The Philippine armed forces chief said Wednesday that five military exercises with the United States, including at least two major naval drills, will be scrapped next year at the direction of President Rodrigo Duterte. Armed forces spokesman Brig. Gen. Restituto Padilla said the 258 exercises include small drills involving only a few soldiers, but that 13 are considered major drills. Padilla said the large-scale "Balikatan" or "shoulder-to-shoulder" exercises will be retained but will focus on humanitarian and disaster response.
